Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Analysis of Trajectories on Riemannian Manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the development of statistical tools for the analysis of complex data structures that arise with the use of modern technology. In many applications, the observations naturally lie on a nonlinear space, such as a sphere, and it is important to study the temporal and spatial behavior of these processes. The research will impact several data-rich applications including visual speech recognition, action/emotion recognition, and the analysis of medical images. This project will use techniques from geometry, statistics, and computer science to develop algorithms and tools that can help practitioners derive much needed insight from these data.

In this research, a comprehensive framework for estimation, registration and analysis of manifold-valued processes is proposed. Functional data analysis in Euclidean spaces has been explored extensively in the literature. In this project, the functions that are studied take values on nonlinear manifolds, rather than in vector spaces. The observed data are noisy and discrete, and observed at random/arbitrary times. Two main problems are investigated: the first involves estimation of smoothing trajectories using time-indexed points. The second problem focuses on the development of a comprehensive framework for joint registration and analysis of multiple manifold-valued processes. The approach takes into account the temporal variability, derives a rate-invariant metric, and generates statistical summaries (sample mean, covariance), which can be subsequently used for registering and modeling multiple trajectories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI has studied the problem of analyzing trajectories on manifolds with applications in active fiber clustering and eye movements. In both applications, data are observed continuously in complex spaces. Statistical tools have been developed to analyze and summarize such data for better clustering and classification.

As a result, one PhD student, Pansujee Dissanayaka, had defensed her dissertation titled “Statistical Analysis of Binocular Eye Gaze Trajectory” in October 2018. Another PhD student, Mengmeng Guo, had defensed the thesis titled “Statistical Analysis of Functional and Shape Data” in June 2019. The joint work on covariance trajectories has been published on Journal of Mathematical Imaging and Vision (“Rate-invariant analysis of covariance trajectories”, Z. Zhang and J. Su et al., JMIV pp 1-18, 2018). A paper titled” Statistical Regression Analysis of Functional and Shape Data” was accepted by Journal of Applied Statistics in 2019 and ready to be published. The PI was also invited to contribute a chapter in a Springer Handbook on "Variational methods for nonlinear geometric data and applications".

The PI had taught a graduate class in summer 2019. Besides, the PI’s work had been presented in multiple international conferences and workshops. The related codes and programs have been shared among peers.
